title: Driver fined £100 for parking over two bays while getting cash in empty car park
text:
Richy Deane parked his car near the cash machine early in the morning before work (Picture: Wales News Service)

A motorist who nipped into a car park for just three minutes to get some cash has been fined because his car was left over two bays.

Richy Deane, 49, received a £100 fine despite the car park being deserted because it was so early while he nipped to the ATM at a shopping centre in Talbot Green, near Cardiff.

Richy, who works early as a cleaning supervisor at Marks and Spencer, said that he will appeal the ‘daft’ charge sent to him by New Generation Parking Management.

He said: ‘I was there less than three minutes and as you can see, the car park was empty and I was not obstructing anyone else from parking.

‘I felt more safe withdrawing cash in the dark, parked somewhere I could jump straight out of the car, get my cash and drive straight off.’

Five days later he received the fine after being spotted by cameras.

Richy was on his way to work before 6am when he stopped to use the cash machine (Picture: Wales News Service)

A spokesman for the parking firm said that ‘common sense must be used in exceptional circumstances’, but insisted that this was not one of those times.

They said that if he pays within 14 days the fine would be reduced to £60 and he has the right to appeal.

The spokesman added: ‘It is important to understand the reason why this car park is a managed area. It is to ensure that spaces are made available on a regular basis for customers using the facilities in the surrounding area, that is achieved by encouraging a regular turnover of spaces.

‘As you will appreciate from the images you have seen, the driver in question parked in a manner which contravened the terms and conditions stated on the signage. Had the driver parked within the confines of a valid marked bay they would have not received a PCN.

‘The terms and conditions on site are valid 24 hours a day, seven days a week, so we must reiterate that the way in which the driver has parked still contravenes these terms regardless of the time.’
